oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photographs and captions from Miss Edith Scott's Memory Book, started July 1957. Her ancestors included the Scott, Deaderick, Crozier, Ramsey, Anderson and Alexander families. Francis Alexander Ramsey Scott (1827-1909) married Margaretta Frances Deaderick (1833-1909) in 1857. They were the parents of eleven children, including daughter Miss Edith Scott (1878-1971). Caption information appears below in the Full Text field.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Here is the same house we have seen, only remodeled. Several rooms added to the back, upstairs and down, and as you see, a tower added to the roof. Building a house as room is needed, certainly makes a comfortable, convenient home. Living there we knew exactly what we needed and built accordingly. The yard was just as nice as the house. We had fruit trees and lovely shrubbery. Sister Lizzie had a green thumb - flowers were her hobby. She had two pits full, and worked there and in her flower beds every day the weather would permit. My mother, too, was a great lover of flowers and worked with them. We had a stable and kept a cow, then we always had a turkey coop for we must have a turkey every Sunday for dinner and other times too. My brothers had an acting pole in the back yard, and what good times we had with that! They would let me play baseball with them, until the boys in the neighborhood would come, then I knew I must get in the house. In this picture we have all grown. Starting at the left: first is Sister Ret, with her hat in her hand; sitting down on the porch at her feet is John Barton; standing next is Frederick William. Behind the post, where you can just see her is Sister Lizzie; and seated next to her is our dear cousin Mack Stewart, who used to visit us frequently and was almost one of the family. She and Sister Lizzie were special friends. Seated next is Mamma; standing is my father; and at his feet is Clarence (Clake we always called him). Next is Annie; then I am standing with my oldest brother Jimmie, who was not in the other picture. Standing at the gate is Frank Ramsey; and seated in the buggy is David Deaderick (Buddy); and with him is Mary. Our house was well located for it was directly opposite the Deaf and Dumb Asylum, and it was just like having a park in front of us. From the back we had a view of "College Hill" - now the University of Tennessee. The three old original buildings, as we saw them, silhouetted against the sky, have long since been taken down, and so has 96 Asylum Street. Henley Street cut off the back yard, and Wall Avenue cut down the house itself.
